subNodes.conversationText: This looks like the one.  It was a pity we couldn't have taken the body to Berdusk, so that he could at least rest near my parents' graves.  To think that he lies in an unmarked grave so far from home--it makes me sad.
I understand. You know, we could probably raise enough money to transport it.
No, not now. Some day--When I have retired from fortune-hunting and vagrancy, perhaps, and returned to Berdusk myself.
For now, though, he can stay here. [Looking around.] I've seen worse crypts, really. And I suppose there's treasure to be had in some of the other graves.
[Jesting.] I am glad that your heart can accomodate both grief and greed.
I am not sure whether to admire or to condemn you, Vroman.  Not everyone can recover from loss so easily.
Sometimes, Milady, I say more than I mean--and sometimes, I say less than I feel.
[Peering around the corner into the crypt antechamber, you see that five zombies have appeared!] Where in the Nine Hells did they come from?
<color=green> [Spot] I do not know, but it wasn't from any of these coffins.  They appear undisturbed.</color>
Quite perceptive.  I noticed the same thing.
Not from the Nine Hells, I hope.
<color=green> [Spellcraft] I can tell that they were recently summoned.  There is still an aura of necromancy here--those creatures are not native to this crypt.</color>
This is truly strange.  I have been in Drawn Swords for a year, and we have had no trouble with undead--from this crypt or elsewhere.
After we're done here, I am sure Brother Anselm would like to know about this.
Let us not rush. These should be easy work for the power of my goddess.
After we're done here, I am sure Brother Anselm would like to know about this.
The body is not what matters in the end, Vroman.  Justice would please Manfred's spirit more.
I doubt Vroman would have wanted vengeance. Things of this world seemed to mean little to him; we were very different. He would prefer a humble tomb in Berdusk to even one of his killers slain.
It is a shame, Vroman, but there is little we can do about it.
This is the grave of Manfred Horner.
This is the grave of Nevin, the Harper illusionist who fooled everyone into believing he was Manfred.
